treatment.reference: Thermococcus peptonophilus sp. nov., a fast-growing, extremely thermophilic archaebacterium isolated from deep-sea hydrothermal vents Arch Microbiol 164:159-164
treatment.description: Cells are cocci, 0.7-2 µm in diameter, occurring mostly singly or in pairs. Multiply by constriction. Motile with a polar tuft of flagella. The cell envelope consists of two layers, the external one is electron-dense. Obligately anaerobic. Temperature range of growth from 60 to 100˚C optimum 85˚C. pH range of growth from pH 3 to 8, with the optimum around pH 6. NaCl concentrations allowing growth range from 1 to 5%; optimum 3%. Sulfur is not essential for growth, although elemental sulfur greatly stimulates growth. Heterotrophic growth on peptone, tryptone, yeast extract, beef extract and/or non-hydrolyzed casein. No growth on free amino acids, sugars, organic acids, or in the absence of organic substrates. Growth is inhibited by rifampicin. G+C content is 52 mol%. Inhabits marine hydrothermal vents in the western Pacific Ocean, specifically found in Izu-Bonin and South Mariana Trough areas. Isolated from hydrothermal fluids. Type strain: Thermococcus peptonophilus OG-1, JCM 9653, Wako-shi, Japan. Not able to use or to grow on sucrose, glucose, maltose, acetate, propionate, pyruvate, succinate, and a mixture of amino acids. Unable to grow autotrophically in the absence of peptides. The presence of NH4Cl had a stimulating effect on growth.
